query: Show the OpenTelemetry export example from the documents.
actual_response:
Certainly! Here is an example of an OpenTelemetry export configuration based on the content from the documents, illustrating how to set up the OpenTelemetry Collector and Fluent Bit to export telemetry data:

OpenTelemetry Collector Configuration:

receivers:
  otlp:
    protocols:
      grpc:
        endpoint: 0.0.0.0:4317
      http:
        endpoint: 0.0.0.0:4318

exporters:
  debug:
    verbosity: detailed

service:
  pipelines:
    traces:
      receivers: [otlp]
      exporters: [debug]
    metrics:
      receivers: [otlp]
      exporters: [debug]
    logs:
      receivers: [otlp]
      exporters: [debug]


This configuration sets up the OTLP receiver to listen on gRPC and HTTP ports.
The debug exporter outputs detailed telemetry data for development or debugging purposes.
Pipelines are defined for traces, metrics, and logs, each using the OTLP receiver and debug exporter.


Running the OpenTelemetry Collector Container:

docker run -p 127.0.0.1:4317:4317 -p 127.0.0.1:4318:4318 \\
  -v $PWD/otel-config.yaml:/etc/otelcol-contrib/config.yaml \\
  otel/opentelemetry-collector-contrib:0.128.0


This command runs the collector container with the above configuration mounted and ports exposed.


Fluent Bit Configuration to Export to OpenTelemetry Collector:

service:
  log_level: info

pipeline:
  inputs:
    - name: dummy
      tag: test
  processors:
    logs:
      - name: opentelemetry_envelope
  outputs:
    - name: opentelemetry
      match: '*'
      host: 127.0.0.1
      port: 4318
      tls: off
      metrics_uri: /v1/metrics
      logs_uri: /v1/logs
      traces_uri: /v1/traces
      log_response_payload: true
    - name: stdout
      match: '*'


Fluent Bit generates dummy log data and processes it with the opentelemetry_envelope processor to set OTEL metadata.
The output is sent to the OpenTelemetry Collector at localhost on port 4318 using the OTLP HTTP endpoints for metrics, logs, and traces.
Additionally, logs are output to stdout for local visibility.


Running Fluent Bit Container:

docker run --rm -it --network=host \\
  -v $PWD/fluent-bit.yaml:/fluent-bit/etc/fluent-bit.yaml:ro \\
  fluent/fluent-bit -c /fluent-bit/etc/fluent-bit.yaml


This runs Fluent Bit with the above configuration, using host networking to communicate with the collector.

This setup demonstrates a basic end-to-end OpenTelemetry export pipeline where Fluent Bit collects and forwards telemetry data to the OpenTelemetry Collector, which then exports it (in this example, to a debug output). This can be extended to export to other backends like Prometheus, Jaeger, or commercial observability platforms by configuring appropriate exporters in the collector.
This example is drawn from detailed tutorials and practical sessions on OpenTelemetry integration with Fluent Bit and Kubernetes environments, providing a solid foundation for building observability pipelines in serverless and cloud-native architectures [1.],  [2.], .
If you want, I can also provide examples for Java or .NET OpenTelemetry exporters or more advanced configurations.
